Authors: Chance Ray Noffsinger, Cathy L Cripps
Title:
Systematic analysis of Russula in the North American Rocky
Mountain Alpine Zone
Keywords:
Alpine, Betula, ITS, rpb2, Salix, Dryas, taxonomy,
Russulaceae
Abstract:
Russula Pers. (Russulales) is an important ectomycorrhizal
fungal genus in alpine and Arctic regions where it occurs with Salix,
Betula, Dryas, and Polygonum, yet a complex phylogenetic analysis of the
genus in these habitats is lacking. This research compared collections
of Russula from the Rocky Mountain alpine (CO, MT, WY) to reference
specimens from Arctic and alpine habitats, mostly in Europe, using an
in-depth morphological study and a phylogenetic analysis of the nuc rDNA
ITS1-5.8S-ITS2 region (ITS barcode) and the second largest subunit of
the RNA polymerase II gene (rpb2). 139 Russula collections were
sequenced including type material. Eight species are reported for this
part of the Rocky Mountain alpine zone, and two from treeline habitats.
This is the first formal report of R. cf. altaica, R. saliceticola, and
R. subrubens from the Rocky Mountains and of R. purpureofusca in North
America. Russula laevis is reported for the first time under this name
with a voucher, and not as an environmental sample. Previous reports of
R. nana and R. laccata are molecularly confirmed. Two species are
reported from subalpine habitats at treeline; R. montana with conifers
and R. cf. altaica with Betula. In this study R. laccata, R. subrubens,
and R. laevis were collected in alpine habitats but have been reported
below treeline in Europe; these species may also be present at lower
elevations in North America. All species have an intercontinental
distribution and have been reported in other alpine or Arctic habitats,
except for one possible endemic. Two unidentified and potentially new
species are discussed. A key to the alpine Russulas of North America is
provided.
